Subject: English
FWKeyIdeaDescription:
The Framework of Ideas presents four broad ideas through which students can engage with writing (see table below). Each idea includes elaborations (general advice and directions schools and teachers could use in the context of their communities and cohorts) and is aligned with four mentor texts (List 2 of the VCAA VCE English and EAL Text List).
To further develop student engagement and writing, schools should actively source additional texts relevant to the key idea and that resonate with their school context and student cohort.

Subject: English
FWKIElaboration: Exploration of place and belonging.

Subject: English
FWKIElaboration: Explorations of physical land and country, local and international, loss of country and dispossession, remembering country and nostalgia, migration, the power of connections with land, climate change and the changing landscape, and imagined countries.

Subject: English
FWKIElaboration: Students could engage with experiences like farming and land management, and with cultural expressions like country music.

Subject: English
FWKIElaboration: Others could explore traditional understandings of Country through Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander knowledge and perspectives.

Subject: English
FWKIElaboration: Explorations of conflict and contest, what it means to protest, the value of protest, the outcomes of protest, personal stories of protest, struggle and war.

Subject: English
FWKIElaboration: Students could explore established figures like Martin Luther King Jr, Rosa Parks and Vida Goldstein, marginalised figures like Pemulwuy and Claudette Colvin, and figures and movements like Greta Thunberg and the BLM protests.

Subject: English
FWKIElaboration: Events like massacres in Australia and the Frontier Wars could be explored as expressions of protest – and the attendant tragedy.

Subject: English
FWKIElaboration: There could also be explorations of the success and failure of protest – and the prescient protests that gained ground after the original protest had faded.

Subject: English
FWKIElaboration: Students could consider individual protest and group protest.

Subject: English
FWKIElaboration: Explorations of ‘life’ or biographical explorations – telling our stories, telling others’ stories, the problem of telling stories, appropriation of stories, who tells the stories and our history, missing stories, marginalised and elevated stories.

Subject: English
FWKIElaboration: Students could explore personal milestones, the effects of key events on their lives, or explore these ideas through the eyes of others.

Subject: English
FWKIElaboration: Students who have migrated can explore their stories of movement and disruption.

Subject: English
FWKIElaboration: They can explore the expectations of change, and the language of a new place and culture.

Subject: English
FWKIElaboration: Explorations of experiences and traditions of play and playing in many cultures and through history.

Subject: English
FWKIElaboration: Students could explore play as it is applied to games, sport, acting and make-believe, music, language and images.

Subject: English
FWKIElaboration: They could also explore concepts of collaboration and connection, digital vs analogue, rules and rule breaking.

Subject: English
FWKIElaboration: There is scope to consider the ways play and play acting can represent the ‘real’ world, and to explore issues associated with using play or play acting to minimise or mitigate against events or actions.

Subject: English
FWKeyIdeaDescription:
Students can explore a variety of textual forms as appropriate to classroom programs and preference.
Textual forms can include but are not limited to short stories, speeches or monologues (with transcripts), essays (comment, opinion, reflective, personal), podcasts (with transcripts), poetry/songs, feature articles (including a series of blog or social media postings) and memoirs and biography.

Subject: English
FWKeyIdeaDescription: The concepts of audience and context are key to creating effective and cohesive writing. The writer needs to consider for whom they are writing, under what circumstances, and for what purpose (see below). The questions to consider when thinking about audience and context could include:

Subject: English
FWKIElaboration: Social connections – how well do I know this audience, and how well do they know me?

Subject: English
FWKIElaboration: Cultural understanding – does the writer share the same cultural understanding as the audience?

Subject: English
FWKIElaboration: Power – who holds power, the writer and/or the audience? To what degree?

Subject: English
FWKIElaboration: Formality/Register – what level of formality would be most appropriate for this audience?

Subject: English
FWKIElaboration: Mode – how will the audience receive this writing – will they read it or will they listen to it?

Subject: English
FWKIElaboration: Site – where will this writing appear and where will the audience receive it (including public, private)?

Subject: English
FWKeyIdeaDescription:
The purpose of the text is closely connected with audience and context, but has another dimension – why is the writer creating this text?
The following four verbs offer overviews of purposes students can explore. Students can explore more than one purpose in their writing.

Subject: English
FWKIElaboration: Express: A student writer seeking to express would explore recounts, storytelling and/or narratives of imagination to engage with actions, events, experiences and/or ideas.

Subject: English
FWKIElaboration: Explain: A student writer seeking to explain would explore cause and effect, and possible consequences of actions, events, experiences and/or ideas.

Subject: English
FWKIElaboration: Reflect: A student writer seeking to reflect would explore experiences of personal discovery that shape their understanding of actions, events, experiences and/or ideas.

Subject: English
FWKIElaboration: Argue: A student writer seeking to argue would explore a point of view, would take a stand and propose solutions to convince others of actions, events, experiences and/or ideas.

Subject: English
FWKeyIdeaDescription: The mentor texts provide opportunities for teachers to explore effective and cohesive writing through vocabulary, text structures and language features, and to consider the purpose, context and audience of the texts. Teachers can use the entire mentor text to provide insight into the overall intention and integrity of the text, and can use extracts to unpack the text structures, language features and vocabulary employed by the author, exploring how these elements successfully interweave with the ideas of the text.
